displayName.text: Citi Bike: E 7 St & Ave A

originalText.text:
A truly special Citibike Station, this gem was first erected in 1783 as part of Great Britain's "Refresh the Lowly Boondocks" initiative during their occupation of New York over the course of the Revolutionary War. In that time, the East Village around Thompkins Square Park was a goat farm owned by one P. Edgar Mandrake, esq., a maritime lawyer and loyalist to the crown.

Mandrake provided land for the British redcoats to camp and play nock-hockey, an early form of the classic bar game "Quarters", as well as drink, train, and learn how to ferment goat milk properly.

The Citibike station was originally a spot to tie up horses or large goats. The soldiers would, after a night of revelry, hop around the edges, singing "Ring About the Roostie", a cruel game akin to "Hot Potato" involving holding roosters by the feet and swinging them around, smacking the livestock on the rear and dodging kicks from the beasts. The loser would be the one who was struck by a hoof, where the winner would give a smack that left the rooster dazed enough to walk around until it fell over, where it was subsequently plucked and prepared for a stew by the (quite literally) "sore loser". It is hypothesized by Early American Studies linguists that this is where the phrase "Winner Winner Chicken Dinner" originated.

Following Cornwallis's surrender at Yorktown, Mandrake's land was ceded to Peter Stuyvesant, whose son eventually gave it to the city for public use. Mandrake left his position and holdings and fled to Canada, though the combination goat and horse hitch remained until the rise of the automobile.

Today, the Citibike station is one of the more highly-trafficked ones in the area, filling up in the evening from the many local residents that call the neighborhood home or frequent the area's nightlife, and emptying before 9 a.m. with the morning commute. 4 stars
